docs.lead_paragraph: A decision by New York State's highest court has added New York to a growing number of states that require psychiatrists to go to court when they want to override a mental patient's refusal to take antipsychotic drugs. Officials in New York and other states say that such a requirement now poses few practical problems, because the number of such patients is small and because the rule is largely an extension of other safeguards. However, state mental-health officials say the patients who most often refuse medication come from a new and growing group - violent, young, predominantly male chronic patients whom psychiatrists describe as the most difficult cases because of their resistance to treatment and their propensity for violent outbursts. While 1 to 2 percent of all patients now refuse drug treatment, the officials said, the problem could worsen if the number of young patients - people from 18 to 35 years old - continues to increase, as it has over the last 10 years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as Congress considers the Reagan Administration's proposals to reduce the nation's Medicaid costs, there is much that can be done at the state level, particularly in New York. The Medicaid program is one of the largest and fastest-growing expenses in the state budget. Medicaid, the health care plan for the indigent - not to be confused with the Medicare plan for the aged - cost New York about $1 billion in 1970. By 1980, the state's expense had risen to $5 billion, and by 1984, the last full year for which figures are available, it had soared again, to $7.8 billion.
